Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diversity Structures Create Illusions of Fairness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today, organizations spend a great deal of time and money to create structures and procedures for managing organizational diversity. However, relatively little is known about how the diversity structures that are created actually affect members of underrepresented groups. This research project focuses on one significant, unintended cost of diversity structures for those they intend to help -- "the illusion of fairness." The investigators propose that diversity structures have the potential to cause an illusion of fairness concerning the treatment of members of underrepresented groups among members of high status groups. This illusion leaves members of high status groups blind to discrimination against underrepresented groups, and unsympathetic toward those who claim to experience discrimination. The research is based upon two theoretical assumptions: 1) most diversity structures do not actually make organizations fairer for members of underrepresented groups; and 2) most high status group members believe that diversity programs make organizations fairer for members of underrepresented groups. The experiments included in this project test whether White Americans believe that diversity programs create procedurally fair environments for members of underrepresented groups, whether the perceptions of procedural fairness for underrepresented group members lead them to be blind to discrimination; whether participants' group status (e.g., Whites or minorities; men or women) and endorsed or primed beliefs that legitimize status differences moderate the illusion of fairness; and whether the illusion of fairness extends to instances of "reverse discrimination" in which high status group members claim to experience discrimination.

As part of the Science of Broadening Participation, this research offers insight into increasing the effectiveness of diversity structures as well as reducing animosity directed at members of underrepresented groups. It will be of interest to researchers and practitioners studying anti-discrimination law and policy, as well as to organizations seeking to build and manage a more diverse workforce. In addition, the research promotes teaching, training, and learning. Both investigators run active teaching labs that include a diverse group of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and undergraduates. These students will be involved in the implementation of this research as well as its dissemination in presentations and papers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organizations spend countless hours and dollars implementing programs for managing organizational diversity. Yet, little is known about how diversity programs affect members of underrepresented groups. This project discovered a significant and unintended consequence of diversity programs---specifically some of these programs seem to harm the very groups they intend to help.  Specifically, across multiple publications and presentations, our research has demonstrated that among members of high status groups (e.g., White Americans, men), diversity programs have the potential to cause an illusion of fairness concerning the treatment of members of low status groups (e.g., racial minorities, women)– an illusion that leaves members of high status groups blind to seeing discrimination against underrepresented groups, and unsympathetic toward those who claim to experience discrimination. Our research demonstrated that members of high status groups believe that diversity programs create procedurally fair environments for members of underrepresented groups, even when it is clear that diversity programs are ineffective and that low status groups continue to face workplace disadvantage. Additionally, our research highlights that sometimes members of low status groups show these same effects; they perceive the mere presence of diversity programs as evidence that organizations are actually fair.

This research has been of interest to scholars and practitioners studying anti-discrimination law and policy, as well as to organizations seeking to build and manage a more diverse workforce. These groups benefit by understanding factors that affect perceived, as these outcomes can shape the experiences of members of underrepresented groups as well as the legal structures and policies needed to protect these groups. Further, the present studies provide suggestions for developing diversity structures that do not further disadvantage members of underrepresented groups.  For instance, diversity training programs could incorporate strategies that help recognize the continuing significance of discrimination against members of underrepresented groups, even as we make progress toward addressing diversity issues. Finally, this project promoted teaching, training, and learning. A diverse group graduate students and undergraduates were involved in this research, contributing toward developing future generations of scientists.
